newsitem.title: UK: NWE fuel oil softens with crude, paper, poor deman.
newsitem.headline: NWE fuel oil softens with crude, paper, poor deman.

text.p: High sulphur cracked fuel oil drifted lower on Wednesday despite being thinly offered. Dealers said the lack of visible demand was knocking off up to $2 a tonne.
High sulphur barges failed to recover even though bunker demand was higher. Barges traded between $122-124 fob ARA with Russian straight-run material in tank seen as a limiter.
High sulphur cracked cargoes were also lower in line with paper.

"There's been so little physical we are all following swaps," said one trader. Physical cargoes were pegged at $114-116 fob NWE. A utility was heard buying a cargo of Russian M-100 at $121 cif NWE, supporting the those in the market that say the overhang of straight-run material has not been cleared.

Low sulphur cracked fuel was marginally softer with buyers unwilling to be locked into what they see as a falling market with fixed prices. The U.S. east coast was seen to be a better bet for holders of cargoes in the Caribs than Europe. Cargoes were put at $126-128 fob NWE, close to paper levels.
A low sulphur barge of 500 tonnes was heard traded at $132 fob ARA, although some dealers thoght the prices was well over the market.
